THE NEWS-LETTER.

Mr. Bernard N. Baker, treasurer of the
committee whose purpose it is to raise a fund
for a memorial to the late Johns Hopkins,
reports satisfactory progress in this work.
A guarantee fund of about $7,000 has already been raised. This, without any further subscriptions, would assure such a testimonial as those participating in the movement feel would, to some extent, at least,
fittingly commemorate the Baltimore philanthropist. It is not sufficient, however, in the
opinion of those having the matter in charge,
to give such a monument as was intended
at the outset of this movement. It was anticipated that at least $15,000 would be required ,and it is the aim of the committee to
realize this sum.
When the limit is reached a meeting of
the subscribers will probably be called for
a general consultation as to the form the
memorial should take. Sculptors will be
invited to submit plans and the city officials
will be consulted as to the most suitable location.
It has been tentatively suggested that it
be a drinking fountain of handsome design,
either on Exchange Place or Hopkins Place.
In the first named locality most of Mr. Hopkins' business life was spent, while the last
was named in his honor by the city. Others
think a statute of the philanthropist in some
prominent uptown section would be a more
suitable recognition.
These are all matters in the future, however.
"The first thing is to collect the needed
fund," said Mr. Baker. "With this in hand,
the other questions should not cause any
great conflict of opinion or delay in execution."
In furtherance of the plan a circular letter has been sent to as many business men
as possible and other citizens likely to take
an interest in this project.
"A feeling exists in Baltimore, we are led
to believe," it says, "that the inestimable
boon conferred upon the city by the Johns
Hopkins Hospital and the Johns Hopkins
University should be recognized by some
suitable memorial to the founder, a memorial

erected by the voluntary contributions of
the people. With a view to ascertaining the
strength of this sentiment, the Municipal Art
Society some months ago opened a subscription list for such a memorial. The exact
form and location of the memorial are to be
left to the judgment of a special committee
to be appointed after requisite funds are in
hand. The small fund in hand, of course,
makes the project feasible, but it is felt that
it would be ungenerous on the part of Baltimoreans to fail to erect to the memory of
Johns Hopkins something much more imposing than the smaller sum would procure."
notable gathering of university men
took place last Saturday night, when
the Hopkins alumni now living in
Virginia gathered to meet Dr. Remsen at a
banquet at Richmond, Va. There are more
than 55 old Hopkins alumni now in that
State.
A committee composed of Dr. W. L. Foushee, of Richmond; Dr. Albert Lefevre, of
Charlottesville; Dr. J. H. Latane, of Lexington, and Prof. Hall Canter, of Ashland, with
the first named as chairman, worked zealousyl for the promotion of a Johns Hopkins
Alumni Association of Virginia. Dr. Remsen made the princpal address, while Dr. E.
A. Alderman, who is one of the few who have
ever received LL. D. from the Hopkins; Dr.
J. M. Page and Dr. Leslie Hall, also spoke.

NE of the best and jolliest of
the Musical Clubs' trips took
place lately, when a dozen picked
men of the Glee Club went over to
Washington to participate in, and incidentally sing, at the second annual banquet of
the University Club of Washington. Over
five hundred sat down to the dinner, which
was a mighty good one, and the Glee Club
covered themselves and the University with
glory by rendering selections between the
acts. At about 12 o'clock the speeches began, and no less important men than President Wilson of Princeton, Speaker Cannon,
Secretary of Agriculture Wilson and others,
responded to the toasts,

THE NEWS-LETTER.
After the banquet the men went to the University Club house, which was put at their
disposal (along with the bar). After a rousing time the men caught the 3 o'clock train,
and got home—.
Well, everybody had a great time and we
hope the University Club will extend another
invitation next year.

The Raving.
Once upon a morning dreary, when my eyes were weak and bleary,
Over many a taint of curious drink tabooed by law;
While I nodded, ice-towels wrapping 'bout my head there came a tapping,
As of someone gently slapping—slapping bricks against my door.
"'Tis some Creditor," I muttered, "tapping at my chamber door—
Only this and nothing more."
Ah, distinctly I remember, it was in the bleak December,
And eaeh separate crying member sought its post upon the floor.
Sadly then I mourned the sorrow--madly I had sought to borrow
From my friends until the morrow—money for this Creditor—
For this irate man of bill-heads, whom the world calls Creditor—
Shameless wretch for evermore.
Thus I sat engaged in guessing, but no syllable expressing
To the wretch whose fiery language burned more brightly as he swore;
This and more, I sat divining, with my head at ease reclining
On the cold towel's icy lining that the ice was melting o'er,
But whose icy dampened lining with the ice still melting o'er,
Shall you guess, ah, nevermore!
Then methought, the air grew denser, perfumed by my unseen censor
Sprung from Creditor whose foot-falls thundered on the bare hall floor.
"Wretch," I cried,"My pard hath sent thee—by my honor, he hath lent me
Money—money and deliv'ranee from my memories, Creditor!
Laugh, oh laugh, you raw-boned tailor, and forget it, Creditor."
Quoth the tailor, "Nevermore."
But the tailor, ever knitting, still is sitting, still is sitting,
O'er the pallid busted debtor behind some other chamber door;
And his eyes have all the gleaming, of a tailor that is scheeming,
And the sunlight o'er him beaming, throws his shadow on the floor;
And my fears for that grim shadow that lies floating on the floor
Shall be lifted—nevermore!

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Our Thirtieth Anniversary.
HE exercises to commemorate the
thirtieth anniversary of the University were held in McCoy Hall
on February 22. The University has
never had a more successful celebration. The speeches of Dr. Lewellys Barker
and Mr. Bonaparte were most interesting,
as they both treated of live topics of the day.
Mr. Bonaparte's remarks about modern naval
warfare were especially interesting as coming from the head of the Naval Department.
Dr. Remsen announced the presentation of
an advance copy of University records, compiled by Dr. Gilman. A bust of Dr. Osler
was then unveiled. This likeness, by a Baltimorean named Hans Schuler, will be a very
valuable addition to the University's collection of busts.
The music was rendered by an orchestra
of twenty-six pieces, led by Mr. Edwin Turnbull, and a part of the Glee Club sang the
"University Ode" and the "Star-Spangled
Banner."
A marked improvement over the last celebration was shown in the seating arrangements. Last year, most of the undergraduates were unable to get seats; but this year
all the students were provided for.
Secretary Bonaparte's address was an
earnest appeal for a strong navy as one of
the best means of maintaining peace.
His plea was not only for public approval
of the appropriations to buy the ships and
guns, but for fair and intelligent criticism,
and last, but far from least, for sympathy
and for proper treatment of the men who
man the guns. He began by quoting Washington's speech to Congress when it first assembled after his second election to the Presidency:
"' I cannot recommend to your notice
measures for the fulfillment of our duties to
the rest of the world without again pressing
upon you the necessity of placing ourselves
in a condition of complete defense and of

T

exacting from them the fulfillment of their
duties toward us. The United States Ought
not to indulge a persuasion that, contrary to
the order of human events, they will forever
keep at a distance those painful appeals to
arms with which the history of every other
nation abounds. There is a rank due to
these United States among nations which
will be withheld, if not absolutely lost, by
the reputation of weakness. If we desire to
avoid insult we must be able to repel it; if
we desire to secure peace, one of the most
powerful instruments of our rising prosperity, it must be known that we are at all times
ready for war.'
"He had already often expressed the same
views, and he continued to urge them upon
his countrymen until the close of his public
life," said Mr. Bonaparte. "In this instance
his injunction may seem to have been more
honored in the breach than in the observance.
At first sight, the American people appears
to have shown its sense of the truth of Washington's words, not by obeying them, but by
disregarding them and paying dearly for the
disobedience. From our birth as a nation to
the present day we have had with us two
very undesirable classes of national advisers
on this subject—those who deem it 'enlightened,' or 'humane' or 'Christian' to try to
persuade themselves and others that, 'contrary to the order of human events,' we will
or can 'forever keep at a distance those painful appeals to arms with which the history
of every other nation abounds,' and those
who deem it statesmanlike and economical to
keep one dollar in the national Treasury, although hoarding it now may mean the spending of ten or a hundred in the near future.
"I have said that liberality shown by the
Congress toward the navy ought to be, as
it undoubtedly will be, discriminating and
judicious. This leads me to speak of the
second great need of the navy, which is,
to my •mind, a thorough and unsparing but

THE NEWS-LETTER.

1

fair and intelligent criticism. Every person
in the service, and especially the Secretary,
as its head, is a legitimate object of perfectly free comment for all the organs of
public opinion. If this hurts his feelings he
must get used to having them hurt—indeed,
if he is, even approximately, the right man
in the right place, he will welcome such
criticism, however unpalatable for a moment,
as a salutary medicine, a valuable aid in his
appointed work.
"But the duty of fair criticism has a negative no less than a positive side. It forbids
unfair criticism, and criticism is surely unfair
when based on willful misrepresentation or
voluntary ignorance of material facts. I
appeal to decent people to avoid becoming
unconscious accomplices in what is often systematic calumny by refusing to give credence
or greater currency to unauthorized reports.
"Finally, my friends, the navy needs—
needs perhaps more imperatively than aught
else--an assurance that the public sympathizes with its work, that the public knows
and feels its value to the nation.
"To recruit our sea service we have never
used press gangs; we have never had recourse to conscription in any form. We trust
with a confidence which the event has hitherto justified to the patriotism and military
Spirit of our seafaring folk for the additional
men we shall need in the event of war. In
time of peace, however, we must make our
service attractive to men such as we shall
need in war if we hope for trained sailors
when that time shall come.
"Doubtless this means a heavy expense,
for we must pay, and we do pay, such men
liberally; but it means something besides expense. The men we seek, and of late have
in large measure secured, will not alienate
their liberties, will not subject themselves
to the restraints of naval discipline, unless
they feel that as sailors they can retain their
self-respect and earn the esteem of their
fellow-Americans.
"To treat these men as outcasts when they
come ashore is to cripple our ships more

0

surely than if their guns were disabled or
their engines put out of gear. In some sort
our trained seamen resemble our smokeless
powder, we must have enough on hand or
subject to call when war begins to serve our
purpose, for the war may well end before we
can manufacture more.
"I have spoken thus earnestly of that
branch of the public service for the moment
committed to my charge because I feel
strongly its paramount, its vital, moment to
the nation's safety and dignity, usefulness
and greatness.
"What kind of nation, if a nation at all,
we should have been now if George Washington had not been born 174 years ago can
be matter of conjecture only; but we may be
absolutely certain that, to become or remain
a nation worthy of his labors and his memory
—a nation he would be glad and proud to
own were he again among us—we must become, if we are not now—and, if we are, we
must ever remain—a nation glad and proud
to maintain and cherish a worthy navy."
THE POWER BEHIND.
'Tis moonlight on the side-walk,
The air is full of frost,
This weather fine and bracing
Should surely not be lost.
With this, I'm sure that Horace
Would take exception not,
And so for sake of Horace,
I'll go out for a trot.

The Hopkins Alumni Association gave a
banquet at the Merchants' Club last Thursday night.
President Henry Herbert Donaldson, of
the association, spoke briefly of the relations
which should exist between the alma mater
and its former students, and then introduced
President Remsen, of the University . Dr.
Remsen pointed out the necessity of encouraging feelings of good fellowship and of
faith in the former students, not only in the
University, but in each other, so that all
could work together in a common cause and
for successful results. He referred to the
fact that he had recently sent a communication to an alumni association of the Hopkins
in Pittsburg; that he had been invited to
attend such a meeting in Richmond and also
in Boston. He feelingly alluded to the fact
that Mr. Josiah Royce, who recently lectured
here, had returned, for the use of the University, a check for $250 given him as compensation for his services.
Dr. Gilman followed Dr. Remsen.
He
spoke of the good work the institution had
done in promoting culture and science, and
said he hoped to see this work continue in
the future as in the past.
Other speakers were Prof. John H. Finley,
of the University of New York; Mr. William
H. Buckler, who spoke of the need of encouraging the University Club; Major R. M. Venable and Mr. B. Howell Griswold, Jr. The
last speaker devoted his time to the discussion of the necessities of the athletic association at the new grounds at Homewood, and
pointed out how it was intended to raise
the money for this purpose.
At the meeting of the association in the
morning the following officers were elected:
President—Dr. William Henry Howell.
Secretary—Mr. Alfred Jenkins Shriver.
Treasurer—Mr. Reuben Carll Foster.
Executive Committee—Dr. Louis P. Hamrurger, Prof. Westel W. Willoughby, Messrs.
William Sherman Bansemer, Stephen Paul
Harwood, Robert Treat Crane and Thomas
Poole Maynard.

MORE ABOUT THE CLASS
VICTORY.
The second match between Hopkins and
Virginia Chess Clubs, played at Charlottesville on February 22, 23, resulted in a brilliant victory for the locals, with the decisive
score of 6 to 2. It is significant that the
Virginia team, in their practice for the contest, had played a team representing the
faculty of the University of Virginia, and
had won the match by the score of 5 to 3.
This victory of ours is especially welcome
since we lost to Virginia two years ago by
the score of 3% to 41/2.
The Hopkins Chess Club was represented
by B. A. Bernstein, '05 Grad., and A. E.
Landry, Grad. The Virginia team consisted
of H. M. Woods, Jr. and E. N. Morse. Professors M. W. Humphreys and R. H. Dabney
of the University of Virginia acted as judges.
The following is the score by rounds:

THE NEWS-LETTER.

STICK WORK.
The schedule is complete, the preliminary
arrangements have been made, and the lacrosse squad has settled down to hard, steady
work in preparation for the first game with
Mount Washington, towards the end of
March. Practice has been held regularly
in the cage and the men are anxiously awaiting the time when they will exchange the
cage for the wide field at Druid Hill Park.
The Junior squad held an outdoor practice
last Friday, and if the present conditions prevail, regular field work can soon be carried
on. On paper the squad shows up very well.
Although several old men will be missed
from the line-up, the majority of last year's
men are back and exhibit a marked improvement over their last year's form.
Of the old defense, F. Blanck, Schmeisser,
and Morse will not be seen in the line-up this
year, while in the attack the only men missing are Chambers and Strobhar. The loss
of these men will be keenly felt, but if reports can be credited, Swarthmore has suffered even more than we have.
In the practice games thus far held in the
cage, several changes in positions have been
noticed, and as the men are still being shifted
about no definite line-up for the initial game
can be prophesied with any degree of certainty.
The men who have been worked regularly
at in-home are Armstrong, of last year's
squad, and Frank, captain of the Freshman

team. Armstrong seems stronger and quicker
than he was last year. His stick work is
undoubtedly improved and he has acquired
a snap and enthusiasm which he did not seem
to have toward the end of last season. Frank
is certainly a find, and if he continues as he
has begun he may reasonably hope to land a
place on the 'Varsity. The position of outhome lies between the two candidates for
in-home and Knipp, one of last year's subs,
who is captain of the Junior twelve. He has
greatly improved in leg work, and this was
his principal handicap last year. His improvement in this line, coupled with his excellent stick work and judgment, is at present delighting the coaches. Several new
men are being used at first attack, but not
much can be said for or against their ability
until the squad gets out of doors and they
have a chance to prove their worth in the
open. Hudgins is back in his old time form,
and generally fills in at 2nd or 3rd attack.
Third attack will undoubtedly be filled by
Dill, last year's captain, but he has not
played that position in the practices, preferring rather to let the new men get the experience. Breyer of the Freshman class has
done well in this position, but he is closely
pushed by Wegefarth, also of '08. Tough,
fully recovered from the injury which he received in the Harvard game of last year, will
no doubt be seen again at center.
MacSherry is back again at 3rd defense,
and with the experience gained last year
should prove much more efficient than for-

THE NEWS-LETTER.
merly. Raleigh, who played second attack
toward the close of last season, promises to
make a strong bid for one of the defense
Positions, as does Erlanger, who has been
changed over from the attack.
Captain Meyer will be seen in one of the
Close defense positions, and Harry Schmeisser, who is working for point, seems likely
to make good. Last, but not least, Walter
Blanck will be back at goal. In fact, no one
else is seeking to rival him.
In the squad are many new men, the most
Promising of whom are Chesney, Mertie,
Branham and Mathias. All that is needed
now to win the championship is hard work,
not only on the part of the lacrosse squad,
but also on the part of the undergraduate
body as a whole. There is no reason why
the lacrosse team should not be supported as
well as the football team. Let the students
get together and "root" for the team at each
and every game.

Y. M. C. A.

The fifth International Convention of the
Student Volunteer Movement for Foreign
Missions opened at Nashville, Tenn., last
Wednesday, with about three thousand delegates in attendance from nearly six hundred
educational in8titutions of this country and
Canada.

evening, but the influence of the Convention
should be felt in the American colleges during the next four years, after which the sixth

C. G. Kelly and J. A. Addison. The Medical
Department Association will also have five
delegates, as follows: R. W. Dunlap, P. T.
Watson, P. W. Harrison, E. C. Cort and P.
C. Jeans. A report of the Convention will

THE NEWS-LETTER.

The Upshot of the Affair.
EAT and dust—more heat and thicker
dust—together with a goodly complement of license, liberty and liniment, ushered the noon-hour of a particular
Fourth of July into Barr:wine Cross Roads.
The mid-day atmosphere seemed charged
with Independence and the flies were busily
writing a Declaration on the mouasses barrel
that stood in a corner of Hike Smith's store.
Already Hike's stock of fireworks had been
distributed throughout the country adjacent
to Barnville Cross Roads, and weary from the
rush of business, Hike was standing behind
the mail window, reading postals and mopping a beaded forehead, so it was with evident irritation that he permitted himself to
glance up at the figure of "Lanky" Bates,
who just them shambled loosely into the
store.
"Kin you let me hey a poun' ef powdor?"
Lanky drawled out. Now "Lanky" was
the thin, over-grown off-shoot of Barnville's
hardest drinker, and possessed arms and legs
which contrasted painfully with his shrunken
clothes and the limitations of his brain. The
boy was weak-minded, his mania being a
passion for planning and executing the most
daring amusements for the children of Barnville's voters, a passion which only the Sunday before had caused consternation among
the worshippers when Lanky, at the head
of a howling tribe of "Injuns," had led a
"raid" on the sacred edifice while a baptism
was in progress.
The memory was still fresh in Hike's mind
as he wrapped up the powder.
"Say, look-a-here, what-a-you goin' to do
with that ar powder?" Hike asked, looking
narrowly at the boy.
"Shootin', I spec" answered Lanky as he
shuffled out.
"That ar boy's gittin' loonier than a
hyener," grumbled Hike, whose ideas of
hyenas were sincere but vague. "Still, 'taint
none ef my business what he's up to," he

H

added, with a lack of curiosity usually
foreign to him.
Lanky continued up the road for a short
distance until he came to a stretch of woods
skirting the pike. Then he stopped and
cautiously looking about him, turned swiftly
into the woods. He had gone but a few
steps when the figure of another boy, Joe
Hanson, appeared suddenly from behind a
tree. A few mystic signs were exchanged
solemnly, and then Lanky asked impressively:
"Is the Avengin' Anerkists tergether
yet?"
"Yes, Chief," answered the younger boy,
shifting uneasily from one bare foot to the
other, and then in a more anxious tone he
asked, "Say, Lank, did yer git it?"
"Git what?" demanded the chieftain with
dignified indifference.
"The powder."
"I did, verily."
The pair moved on into the woods, following a shallow brook until they came to a
secluded spot where stood the tumbled remains of a mill. On the banks of the millrace sat four other bare-foot youngsters,
ranging in age from about eleven years to
fourteen.
"Men, and feller anerkists," began the
chief, laying beside him the package of powder, the time hes corn' fer our revenge! Be
ye all ready?"
The general wording of this sentence might
have been traced to the leaves of the dime
novel protruding from Lanky's hip-pocket,
but it had the desired effect. A half audible
response resulted.
"Ma, she give me a awful lickin"bout
thet raid Sunday. She said she didn't know
as I could come out ternight," ventured one
of the "anerkists," wriggling his toes uncomfortably.
."Huh," sniffed the leader, whose ideas of
mothers were not born of any remembrance

THE NEWS-LETTER.
of his own, "You're a beaut anerkist, you
are, Sammy Bean, gittin' skeered already.
Ef you was a-goin' to drop out, what did
you sign the Bloody Oath fer?"
"I ain't no more skeered than you are,
Lanky Booze Who said I was a-goin ter
drop out? I was jest a-remindin' you in case
I didn't turn up ternight."
"Feller anerkists," began Lanky afresh,
"we has been done dirty mean by Cap'n
Boaster fer the last time. You all know as
it was him who told on us fer swipin' Squire
Court's apples, en gittin' you fellers a lickin'
fer goin' in swimmin' on Sundays. Yer all
know, too, as he his a-goin' ter make a
speech at the open-air celebrashun ternight.
He thinks he's goin' ter be the hull show,
too. Well, we've all sweared ter fix him.
Let's git ready."
Some one of the "anerkists" produced an
old hot-water bag, which Lanky filled with
his powder, and to which he attached a long,
grease-dipped fuse. When these simple preparations were completed, Lanky dismissed
the "Avengin' Anerkists" with instructions
to meet him at the church after supper.
* * *
All Barnville was assembled around the
platform outside the school-house, when Captain Boaster rose to make his address. His
ample figure was clothed in a dress coat and
vest of ancient cut, steel striped trousers, a
red tie, and a glorious white stiff shirt, specially iron for the occasion, which creaked and
cracked painfully as the orator spoke.
Parting with an evident nervousness from
his re-assuring quid, and after a reviving use
of his bandana handkerchief, he launched
forth.
"Feller citizens of the town of Barnville
Cross Roads, you hey come tergither this
grand night ter celebrate one ef the best
things ef hist'ry—the signin' ef the Declaration ef Independence. I ain't no orator es
Brutus was, but ev'ry time I think of George
Washington, I am filled with pride fer my
country, en my soul is raised—"
A muffled roar closed the sentence, and,
as if to suit his actions to his utterance, the

11

Captain's bodily and spirtual self rose into
the air in a most inglorious manner. In fact
the entire platform was assisting in the soulraising process.
At first the audience was too terror-stricken
tO move, and then with a common impulse,
rushed to where the orator lay. Luckily,
the only injury which he received was to
his shirtfront, which, bolstering up his disheveled beard, was smeared and blackened
beyond the possible succor of Mrs. Boaster's
wash-tubs.
The "Avengin' Anerkists were avenged.

OBITUARY.
R. Frederick W. Hilbert, a graduate student in the Economic
Department, died suddenly on
a Sturday, February 17. His funeral
took place on the following Tuesday. In
token uf their esteem for Mr. Hilbert, the
faculty and members of his department suspended exercises for the day. Dean Griffin,
Professors Hollander, Vincent, Ballagh and
Barnett and others of the University were
present.
Mr. Hilbert was born in 1871. After taking the degree of Master of Arts at RandolphMacon, he bought out the interest in the
Franklin University School for Boys, where,
for several years, he conducted a successful
preparatory school. In 1902 he began graduate work at the Hopkins and was to take
the degree of Doctor of Philosophy in June.
Mr. filbert's special work was a study of
"Collective Bargaining in the United
States." He spent three summers visiting
employers and trade unions, in which time
he became very familiar with the relations
between employer and employee. He had
already published some excellent contributions to the Labor Question. "Mr. Hilbert
was a valuable man," said Dr. Barnett,"and
the Department of Political Economy will
miss him greatly."

With Other Universities.
At a meeting of the faculty of the University of Wisconsin, that body affirmed its preference for the suspension of intercollegiate
football between the universities of the Middle West for a period of two years. It was
decided to request Prof. Angel, of Michigan,
to call a second conference of the nine universities of the Middle West for this end.

A Municipal Government Club has recently
been formed at Amherst.

By a mass-meeting of the students at Bowdoin, it was decided to elect all officers of
classes and collegiate enterprises by ballot.
In this way, it is hoped that electioneering
will be done away with.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Mr. Bernard N. Baker, treasurer of the
committee whose purpose it is to raise a fund
for a memorial to the late Johns Hopkins,
reports satisfactory progress in this work.
A guarantee fund of about $7,000 has already been raised. This, without any further subscriptions, would assure such a testimonial as those participating in the movement feel would, to some extent, at least,
fittingly commemorate the Baltimore philanthropist. It is not sufficient, however, in the
opinion of those having the matter in charge,
to give such a monument as was intended
at the outset of this movement. It was anticipated that at least $15,000 would be required ,and it is the aim of the committee to
realize this sum.
When the limit is reached a meeting of
the subscribers will probably be called for
a general consultation as to the form the
memorial should take. Sculptors will be
invited to submit plans and the city officials
will be consulted as to the most suitable location.
It has been tentatively suggested that it
be a drinking fountain of handsome design,
either on Exchange Place or Hopkins Place.
In the first named locality most of Mr. Hopkins' business life was spent, while the last
was named in his honor by the city. Others
think a statute of the philanthropist in some
prominent uptown section would be a more
suitable recognition.
These are all matters in the future, however.
"The first thing is to collect the needed
fund," said Mr. Baker. "With this in hand,
the other questions should not cause any
great conflict of opinion or delay in execution."
In furtherance of the plan a circular letter has been sent to as many business men
as possible and other citizens likely to take
an interest in this project.
"A feeling exists in Baltimore, we are led
to believe," it says, "that the inestimable
boon conferred upon the city by the Johns
Hopkins Hospital and the Johns Hopkins
University should be recognized by some
suitable memorial to the founder, a memorial

erected by the voluntary contributions of
the people. With a view to ascertaining the
strength of this sentiment, the Municipal Art
Society some months ago opened a subscription list for such a memorial. The exact
form and location of the memorial are to be
left to the judgment of a special committee
to be appointed after requisite funds are in
hand. The small fund in hand, of course,
makes the project feasible, but it is felt that
it would be ungenerous on the part of Baltimoreans to fail to erect to the memory of
Johns Hopkins something much more imposing than the smaller sum would procure."
notable gathering of university men

The Raving.
Once upon a morning dreary, when my eyes were weak and bleary,
Over many a taint of curious drink tabooed by law;
While I nodded, ice-towels wrapping 'bout my head there came a tapping,
As of someone gently slapping—slapping bricks against my door.
"'Tis some Creditor," I muttered, "tapping at my chamber door—
Only this and nothing more."
Ah, distinctly I remember, it was in the bleak December,
And eaeh separate crying member sought its post upon the floor.
Sadly then I mourned the sorrow--madly I had sought to borrow
From my friends until the morrow—money for this Creditor—
For this irate man of bill-heads, whom the world calls Creditor—
Shameless wretch for evermore.
Thus I sat engaged in guessing, but no syllable expressing
To the wretch whose fiery language burned more brightly as he swore;
This and more, I sat divining, with my head at ease reclining
On the cold towel's icy lining that the ice was melting o'er,
But whose icy dampened lining with the ice still melting o'er,
Shall you guess, ah, nevermore!
Then methought, the air grew denser, perfumed by my unseen censor
Sprung from Creditor whose foot-falls thundered on the bare hall floor.
"Wretch," I cried,"My pard hath sent thee—by my honor, he hath lent me
Money—money and deliv'ranee from my memories, Creditor!
Laugh, oh laugh, you raw-boned tailor, and forget it, Creditor."
Quoth the tailor, "Nevermore."
But the tailor, ever knitting, still is sitting, still is sitting,
O'er the pallid busted debtor behind some other chamber door;
And his eyes have all the gleaming, of a tailor that is scheeming,
And the sunlight o'er him beaming, throws his shadow on the floor;
And my fears for that grim shadow that lies floating on the floor
Shall be lifted—nevermore!

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Our Thirtieth Anniversary.
HE exercises to commemorate the
thirtieth anniversary of the University were held in McCoy Hall
on February 22. The University has
never had a more successful celebration. The speeches of Dr. Lewellys Barker
and Mr. Bonaparte were most interesting,
as they both treated of live topics of the day.
Mr. Bonaparte's remarks about modern naval
warfare were especially interesting as coming from the head of the Naval Department.
Dr. Remsen announced the presentation of
an advance copy of University records, compiled by Dr. Gilman. A bust of Dr. Osler
was then unveiled. This likeness, by a Baltimorean named Hans Schuler, will be a very
valuable addition to the University's collection of busts.
The music was rendered by an orchestra
of twenty-six pieces, led by Mr. Edwin Turnbull, and a part of the Glee Club sang the
"University Ode" and the "Star-Spangled
Banner."
A marked improvement over the last celebration was shown in the seating arrangements. Last year, most of the undergraduates were unable to get seats; but this year
all the students were provided for.
Secretary Bonaparte's address was an
earnest appeal for a strong navy as one of
the best means of maintaining peace.
His plea was not only for public approval
of the appropriations to buy the ships and
guns, but for fair and intelligent criticism,
and last, but far from least, for sympathy
and for proper treatment of the men who
man the guns. He began by quoting Washington's speech to Congress when it first assembled after his second election to the Presidency:
"' I cannot recommend to your notice
measures for the fulfillment of our duties to
the rest of the world without again pressing
upon you the necessity of placing ourselves
in a condition of complete defense and of

T

exacting from them the fulfillment of their
duties toward us. The United States Ought
not to indulge a persuasion that, contrary to
the order of human events, they will forever
keep at a distance those painful appeals to
arms with which the history of every other
nation abounds. There is a rank due to
these United States among nations which
will be withheld, if not absolutely lost, by
the reputation of weakness. If we desire to
avoid insult we must be able to repel it; if
we desire to secure peace, one of the most
powerful instruments of our rising prosperity, it must be known that we are at all times
ready for war.'
"He had already often expressed the same
views, and he continued to urge them upon
his countrymen until the close of his public
life," said Mr. Bonaparte. "In this instance
his injunction may seem to have been more
honored in the breach than in the observance.
At first sight, the American people appears
to have shown its sense of the truth of Washington's words, not by obeying them, but by
disregarding them and paying dearly for the
disobedience. From our birth as a nation to
the present day we have had with us two
very undesirable classes of national advisers
on this subject—those who deem it 'enlightened,' or 'humane' or 'Christian' to try to
persuade themselves and others that, 'contrary to the order of human events,' we will
or can 'forever keep at a distance those painful appeals to arms with which the history
of every other nation abounds,' and those
who deem it statesmanlike and economical to
keep one dollar in the national Treasury, although hoarding it now may mean the spending of ten or a hundred in the near future.
"I have said that liberality shown by the
Congress toward the navy ought to be, as
it undoubtedly will be, discriminating and
judicious. This leads me to speak of the
second great need of the navy, which is,
to my •mind, a thorough and unsparing but

THE NEWS-LETTER.

1

fair and intelligent criticism. Every person
in the service, and especially the Secretary,
as its head, is a legitimate object of perfectly free comment for all the organs of
public opinion. If this hurts his feelings he
must get used to having them hurt—indeed,
if he is, even approximately, the right man
in the right place, he will welcome such
criticism, however unpalatable for a moment,
as a salutary medicine, a valuable aid in his
appointed work.
"But the duty of fair criticism has a negative no less than a positive side. It forbids
unfair criticism, and criticism is surely unfair
when based on willful misrepresentation or
voluntary ignorance of material facts. I
appeal to decent people to avoid becoming
unconscious accomplices in what is often systematic calumny by refusing to give credence
or greater currency to unauthorized reports.
"Finally, my friends, the navy needs—
needs perhaps more imperatively than aught
else--an assurance that the public sympathizes with its work, that the public knows
and feels its value to the nation.
"To recruit our sea service we have never
used press gangs; we have never had recourse to conscription in any form. We trust
with a confidence which the event has hitherto justified to the patriotism and military
Spirit of our seafaring folk for the additional
men we shall need in the event of war. In
time of peace, however, we must make our
service attractive to men such as we shall
need in war if we hope for trained sailors
when that time shall come.
"Doubtless this means a heavy expense,
for we must pay, and we do pay, such men
liberally; but it means something besides expense. The men we seek, and of late have
in large measure secured, will not alienate
their liberties, will not subject themselves
to the restraints of naval discipline, unless
they feel that as sailors they can retain their
self-respect and earn the esteem of their
fellow-Americans.
"To treat these men as outcasts when they
come ashore is to cripple our ships more

0

surely than if their guns were disabled or
their engines put out of gear. In some sort
our trained seamen resemble our smokeless
powder, we must have enough on hand or
subject to call when war begins to serve our
purpose, for the war may well end before we
can manufacture more.
"I have spoken thus earnestly of that
branch of the public service for the moment
committed to my charge because I feel
strongly its paramount, its vital, moment to
the nation's safety and dignity, usefulness
and greatness.
"What kind of nation, if a nation at all,
we should have been now if George Washington had not been born 174 years ago can
be matter of conjecture only; but we may be
absolutely certain that, to become or remain
a nation worthy of his labors and his memory
—a nation he would be glad and proud to
own were he again among us—we must become, if we are not now—and, if we are, we
must ever remain—a nation glad and proud
to maintain and cherish a worthy navy."

The Hopkins Alumni Association gave a
banquet at the Merchants' Club last Thursday night.
President Henry Herbert Donaldson, of
the association, spoke briefly of the relations
which should exist between the alma mater
and its former students, and then introduced
President Remsen, of the University . Dr.
Remsen pointed out the necessity of encouraging feelings of good fellowship and of
faith in the former students, not only in the
University, but in each other, so that all
could work together in a common cause and
for successful results. He referred to the
fact that he had recently sent a communication to an alumni association of the Hopkins
in Pittsburg; that he had been invited to
attend such a meeting in Richmond and also
in Boston. He feelingly alluded to the fact
that Mr. Josiah Royce, who recently lectured
here, had returned, for the use of the University, a check for $250 given him as compensation for his services.
Dr. Gilman followed Dr. Remsen.
He
spoke of the good work the institution had
done in promoting culture and science, and
said he hoped to see this work continue in
the future as in the past.
Other speakers were Prof. John H. Finley,
of the University of New York; Mr. William
H. Buckler, who spoke of the need of encouraging the University Club; Major R. M. Venable and Mr. B. Howell Griswold, Jr. The
last speaker devoted his time to the discussion of the necessities of the athletic association at the new grounds at Homewood, and
pointed out how it was intended to raise
the money for this purpose.
At the meeting of the association in the
morning the following officers were elected:
President—Dr. William Henry Howell.
Secretary—Mr. Alfred Jenkins Shriver.
Treasurer—Mr. Reuben Carll Foster.
Executive Committee—Dr. Louis P. Hamrurger, Prof. Westel W. Willoughby, Messrs.
William Sherman Bansemer, Stephen Paul
Harwood, Robert Treat Crane and Thomas
Poole Maynard.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

STICK WORK.
The schedule is complete, the preliminary
arrangements have been made, and the lacrosse squad has settled down to hard, steady
work in preparation for the first game with
Mount Washington, towards the end of
March. Practice has been held regularly
in the cage and the men are anxiously awaiting the time when they will exchange the
cage for the wide field at Druid Hill Park.
The Junior squad held an outdoor practice
last Friday, and if the present conditions prevail, regular field work can soon be carried
on. On paper the squad shows up very well.
Although several old men will be missed
from the line-up, the majority of last year's
men are back and exhibit a marked improvement over their last year's form.
Of the old defense, F. Blanck, Schmeisser,
and Morse will not be seen in the line-up this
year, while in the attack the only men missing are Chambers and Strobhar. The loss
of these men will be keenly felt, but if reports can be credited, Swarthmore has suffered even more than we have.
In the practice games thus far held in the
cage, several changes in positions have been
noticed, and as the men are still being shifted
about no definite line-up for the initial game
can be prophesied with any degree of certainty.
The men who have been worked regularly
at in-home are Armstrong, of last year's
squad, and Frank, captain of the Freshman

team. Armstrong seems stronger and quicker
than he was last year. His stick work is
undoubtedly improved and he has acquired
a snap and enthusiasm which he did not seem
to have toward the end of last season. Frank
is certainly a find, and if he continues as he
has begun he may reasonably hope to land a
place on the 'Varsity. The position of outhome lies between the two candidates for
in-home and Knipp, one of last year's subs,
who is captain of the Junior twelve. He has
greatly improved in leg work, and this was
his principal handicap last year. His improvement in this line, coupled with his excellent stick work and judgment, is at present delighting the coaches. Several new
men are being used at first attack, but not
much can be said for or against their ability
until the squad gets out of doors and they
have a chance to prove their worth in the
open. Hudgins is back in his old time form,
and generally fills in at 2nd or 3rd attack.
Third attack will undoubtedly be filled by
Dill, last year's captain, but he has not
played that position in the practices, preferring rather to let the new men get the experience. Breyer of the Freshman class has
done well in this position, but he is closely
pushed by Wegefarth, also of '08. Tough,
fully recovered from the injury which he received in the Harvard game of last year, will
no doubt be seen again at center.
MacSherry is back again at 3rd defense,
and with the experience gained last year
should prove much more efficient than for-

THE NEWS-LETTER.
merly. Raleigh, who played second attack
toward the close of last season, promises to
make a strong bid for one of the defense
Positions, as does Erlanger, who has been
changed over from the attack.
Captain Meyer will be seen in one of the
Close defense positions, and Harry Schmeisser, who is working for point, seems likely
to make good. Last, but not least, Walter
Blanck will be back at goal. In fact, no one
else is seeking to rival him.
In the squad are many new men, the most
Promising of whom are Chesney, Mertie,
Branham and Mathias. All that is needed
now to win the championship is hard work,
not only on the part of the lacrosse squad,
but also on the part of the undergraduate
body as a whole. There is no reason why
the lacrosse team should not be supported as
well as the football team. Let the students
get together and "root" for the team at each
and every game.

Wednesday, with about three thousand delegates in attendance from nearly six hundred

Canada.

Department Association will also have five
delegates, as follows: R. W. Dunlap, P. T.
Watson, P. W. Harrison, E. C. Cort and P.
C. Jeans. A report of the Convention will

A FAT PROPOSITION.

There once was a lady named Raft,
At whose size most everyone laughed;
"Oh, you can't worry me,"
She said with much glee,
"Good law, why just think of Taft!"

A PROTECTED INDUSTRY.
She asked the postman if he feared
The night so dark, the howling gale;
"Why not at all," the postman said,
"You see, I have a coat of mail!"

THE NEWS-LETTER.

The Upshot of the Affair.
EAT and dust—more heat and thicker
dust—together with a goodly complement of license, liberty and liniment, ushered the noon-hour of a particular
Fourth of July into Barr:wine Cross Roads.
The mid-day atmosphere seemed charged
with Independence and the flies were busily
writing a Declaration on the mouasses barrel
that stood in a corner of Hike Smith's store.
Already Hike's stock of fireworks had been
distributed throughout the country adjacent
to Barnville Cross Roads, and weary from the
rush of business, Hike was standing behind
the mail window, reading postals and mopping a beaded forehead, so it was with evident irritation that he permitted himself to
glance up at the figure of "Lanky" Bates,
who just them shambled loosely into the
store.
"Kin you let me hey a poun' ef powdor?"
Lanky drawled out. Now "Lanky" was
the thin, over-grown off-shoot of Barnville's
hardest drinker, and possessed arms and legs
which contrasted painfully with his shrunken
clothes and the limitations of his brain. The
boy was weak-minded, his mania being a
passion for planning and executing the most
daring amusements for the children of Barnville's voters, a passion which only the Sunday before had caused consternation among
the worshippers when Lanky, at the head
of a howling tribe of "Injuns," had led a
"raid" on the sacred edifice while a baptism
was in progress.
The memory was still fresh in Hike's mind
as he wrapped up the powder.
"Say, look-a-here, what-a-you goin' to do
with that ar powder?" Hike asked, looking
narrowly at the boy.
"Shootin', I spec" answered Lanky as he
shuffled out.
"That ar boy's gittin' loonier than a
hyener," grumbled Hike, whose ideas of
hyenas were sincere but vague. "Still, 'taint
none ef my business what he's up to," he

H

added, with a lack of curiosity usually
foreign to him.
Lanky continued up the road for a short
distance until he came to a stretch of woods
skirting the pike. Then he stopped and
cautiously looking about him, turned swiftly
into the woods. He had gone but a few
steps when the figure of another boy, Joe
Hanson, appeared suddenly from behind a
tree. A few mystic signs were exchanged
solemnly, and then Lanky asked impressively:
"Is the Avengin' Anerkists tergether
yet?"
"Yes, Chief," answered the younger boy,
shifting uneasily from one bare foot to the
other, and then in a more anxious tone he
asked, "Say, Lank, did yer git it?"
"Git what?" demanded the chieftain with
dignified indifference.
"The powder."
"I did, verily."
The pair moved on into the woods, following a shallow brook until they came to a
secluded spot where stood the tumbled remains of a mill. On the banks of the millrace sat four other bare-foot youngsters,
ranging in age from about eleven years to
fourteen.
"Men, and feller anerkists," began the
chief, laying beside him the package of powder, the time hes corn' fer our revenge! Be
ye all ready?"
The general wording of this sentence might
have been traced to the leaves of the dime
novel protruding from Lanky's hip-pocket,
but it had the desired effect. A half audible
response resulted.
"Ma, she give me a awful lickin"bout
thet raid Sunday. She said she didn't know
as I could come out ternight," ventured one
of the "anerkists," wriggling his toes uncomfortably.
."Huh," sniffed the leader, whose ideas of
mothers were not born of any remembrance

THE NEWS-LETTER.
of his own, "You're a beaut anerkist, you
are, Sammy Bean, gittin' skeered already.
Ef you was a-goin' to drop out, what did
you sign the Bloody Oath fer?"
"I ain't no more skeered than you are,
Lanky Booze Who said I was a-goin ter
drop out? I was jest a-remindin' you in case
I didn't turn up ternight."
"Feller anerkists," began Lanky afresh,
"we has been done dirty mean by Cap'n
Boaster fer the last time. You all know as
it was him who told on us fer swipin' Squire
Court's apples, en gittin' you fellers a lickin'
fer goin' in swimmin' on Sundays. Yer all
know, too, as he his a-goin' ter make a
speech at the open-air celebrashun ternight.
He thinks he's goin' ter be the hull show,
too. Well, we've all sweared ter fix him.
Let's git ready."
Some one of the "anerkists" produced an
old hot-water bag, which Lanky filled with
his powder, and to which he attached a long,
grease-dipped fuse. When these simple preparations were completed, Lanky dismissed
the "Avengin' Anerkists" with instructions
to meet him at the church after supper.
* * *
All Barnville was assembled around the
platform outside the school-house, when Captain Boaster rose to make his address. His
ample figure was clothed in a dress coat and
vest of ancient cut, steel striped trousers, a
red tie, and a glorious white stiff shirt, specially iron for the occasion, which creaked and
cracked painfully as the orator spoke.
Parting with an evident nervousness from
his re-assuring quid, and after a reviving use
of his bandana handkerchief, he launched
forth.
"Feller citizens of the town of Barnville
Cross Roads, you hey come tergither this
grand night ter celebrate one ef the best
things ef hist'ry—the signin' ef the Declaration ef Independence. I ain't no orator es
Brutus was, but ev'ry time I think of George
Washington, I am filled with pride fer my
country, en my soul is raised—"
A muffled roar closed the sentence, and,
as if to suit his actions to his utterance, the

11

Captain's bodily and spirtual self rose into
the air in a most inglorious manner. In fact
the entire platform was assisting in the soulraising process.
At first the audience was too terror-stricken
tO move, and then with a common impulse,
rushed to where the orator lay. Luckily,
the only injury which he received was to
his shirtfront, which, bolstering up his disheveled beard, was smeared and blackened
beyond the possible succor of Mrs. Boaster's
wash-tubs.
The "Avengin' Anerkists were avenged.

OBITUARY.
R. Frederick W. Hilbert, a graduate student in the Economic
Department, died suddenly on
a Sturday, February 17. His funeral
took place on the following Tuesday. In
token uf their esteem for Mr. Hilbert, the
faculty and members of his department suspended exercises for the day. Dean Griffin,
Professors Hollander, Vincent, Ballagh and
Barnett and others of the University were
present.
Mr. Hilbert was born in 1871. After taking the degree of Master of Arts at RandolphMacon, he bought out the interest in the
Franklin University School for Boys, where,
for several years, he conducted a successful
preparatory school. In 1902 he began graduate work at the Hopkins and was to take
the degree of Doctor of Philosophy in June.
Mr. filbert's special work was a study of
"Collective Bargaining in the United
States." He spent three summers visiting
employers and trade unions, in which time
he became very familiar with the relations
between employer and employee. He had
already published some excellent contributions to the Labor Question. "Mr. Hilbert
was a valuable man," said Dr. Barnett,"and
the Department of Political Economy will
miss him greatly."

With Other Universities.
At a meeting of the faculty of the University of Wisconsin, that body affirmed its preference for the suspension of intercollegiate
football between the universities of the Middle West for a period of two years. It was
decided to request Prof. Angel, of Michigan,
to call a second conference of the nine universities of the Middle West for this end.

A Municipal Government Club has recently
been formed at Amherst.

By a mass-meeting of the students at Bowdoin, it was decided to elect all officers of
classes and collegiate enterprises by ballot.
In this way, it is hoped that electioneering
will be done away with.
